meanings.definition: Of no real value or importance; trifling
meanings.sent1: The decision to wear mismatched socks was nugatory in the grand scheme of things.
meanings.sent2: Her nugatory attempt to fix the leaky faucet only made it worse.
meanings.sent3: The cat's nugatory efforts to catch the laser pointer entertained the whole family.
meanings.sent4: His apology felt as nugatory as trying to stop a waterfall with a bucket.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's praise meant so much more to the student than any nugatory material possession.

meanings.sent1: The nugatory amount of sugar in his coffee made no difference to the taste.
meanings.sent2: Her nugatory attempts to learn the piano never progressed beyond basic scales.
meanings.sent3: The squirrel's nugatory efforts to reach the bird feeder left it frustrated but determined.
meanings.sent4: The old, rusted key proved nugatory in opening the mysterious chest.
meanings.sent5: The nugatory amount of rain did little to quench the thirsty plants.

meanings.definition: Having no force or effect; ineffective
meanings.sent1: The nugatory law was rarely enforced and often ignored by the citizens.
meanings.sent2: His nugatory attempts to convince her to change her mind fell on deaf ears.
meanings.sent3: The magician's nugatory spell failed to make the rabbit disappear, much to the audience's amusement.
meanings.sent4: The general's nugatory strategy led to a swift defeat in battle.
meanings.sent5: The nugatory lock offered no resistance to the skilled locksmith.
